site_name: NATURAL HISTORY EDUCATION CO OF MIDSOUTH

citations.narrative:
The facility has not yet made and maintained a written record of the acquisition information (as much as is known as birds
were obtained prior to birds being regulated) for the eagle owl and the buteo buteo owned by the facility. Acquisition
records for animals owned or otherwise acquired by the facility should include the name and address of the person from
whom the animals were acquired, the acquisition date, the species of animal and the number of animals. These records
are important for legal and medical tracing of the animals. The facility shall make, keep and maintain records or forms
which fully and correctly disclose the required acquisition information concerning animals purchased or otherwise
acquired, owned or otherwise in their possession. Correct by 11/15/2024.

The indoor building housing the mammals is in need of cleaning and general housekeeping. The floors and surfaces of
items within the building are dirty with a grey brown layer of dirt and dust. There are accumulations of haphazardly stored
items, equipment and furniture in the animal areas that make it difficult to move around to get to the animal enclosures
and to clean and provide proper husbandry practices. The dirty clutter also provides places for pests to reside and
contributes to odors. The shelves and surfaces in the refrigerator and freezer used to store animal foods are also in need
of cleaning of food debris and dirt to help prevent contamination of the food. The plastic food bins containing bags of feed
are coated with a grey film of dust and dirt.
Premises including the building housing the mammals shall be kept clean and in good repair in order to protect the
animals and to facilitate the prescribed husbandry practices set forth in this subpart. Correct by 11/15/2024.

The housing enclosures (made of chain link) for the eagle owl and the buteo buteo are not designed and constructed to
employ security measures that contain the birds securely. The purpose of security measures such as safety doors,
entry/exit doors to the primary enclosure that are double-door or other equivalent systems is to prevent escape of the
birds. The housing facilities for all birds must employ security measures that contain all birds securely. Correct by
11/15/2024.

The primary enclosures for the eagle owl and the buteo buteo are not constructed so that they provide appropriate shelter
and protection for each bird from climatic and environmental conditions. Both enclosures include a long but narrow shelter
structure which is three feet or more in length but only about a foot deep. One of the long sides is open completely to the
elements. When the birds sit on the perch provided near the opening of the long side in these shelter structures they are
still exposed to conditions such as rain, other precipitation and wind. Exposure to weather conditions such as precipitation
and cold winds may be detrimental to the health and well-being of the birds. Primary enclosures for birds must be
constructed and maintained so as to provide shelter and protection for each bird from climatic and environmental
conditions that may be detrimental. Correct by 11/15/2024.

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
The facility does not currently have a written plan to address environment enhancement for the bird species maintained.
The plan must address the social grouping needs, environmental enrichment needs and any special considerations to
ensure the psychological well-being of the birds. The facility must develop, document, and follow a species-appropriate
plan for the environment enhancement of birds that is in accordance with currently accepted professional standards and is
approved by the attending veterinarian.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
2.75(b)(1) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
The facility has not yet made and maintained a written record of the acquisition information (as much as is known as birds 
were obtained prior to birds being regulated) for the eagle owl and the buteo buteo owned by the facility. Acquisition 
records for animals owned or otherwise acquired by the facility should include the name and address of the person from 
whom the animals were acquired, the acquisition date, the species of animal and the number of animals. These records 
are important for legal and medical tracing of the animals. The facility shall make, keep and maintain records or forms 
which fully and correctly disclose the required acquisition information concerning animals purchased or otherwise 
acquired, owned or otherwise in their possession. Correct by 11/15/2024. 
3.131(c) 
   
Sanitation. 
The indoor building housing the mammals is in need of cleaning and general housekeeping. The floors and surfaces of 
items within the building are dirty with a grey brown layer of dirt and dust. There are accumulations of haphazardly stored 
items, equipment and furniture in the animal areas that make it difficult to move around to get to the animal enclosures 
and to clean and provide proper husbandry practices. The dirty clutter also provides places for pests to reside and 
contributes to odors. The shelves and surfaces in the refrigerator and freezer used to store animal foods are also in need 
of cleaning of food debris and dirt to help prevent contamination of the food. The plastic food bins containing bags of feed 
are coated with a grey film of dust and dirt.  
Premises including the building housing the mammals shall be kept clean and in good repair in order to protect the 
animals and to facilitate the prescribed husbandry practices set forth in this subpart. Correct by 11/15/2024. 
3.150(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
The housing enclosures (made of chain link) for the eagle owl and the buteo buteo are not designed and constructed to 
employ security measures that contain the birds securely. The purpose of security measures such as safety doors, 
entry/exit doors to the primary enclosure that are double-door or other equivalent systems is to prevent escape of the 
birds. The housing facilities for all birds must employ security measures that contain all birds securely. Correct by 
11/15/2024.

3.153(a)(1)(vi) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
The primary enclosures for the eagle owl and the buteo buteo are not constructed so that they provide appropriate shelter 
and protection for each bird from climatic and environmental conditions. Both enclosures include a long but narrow shelter 
structure which is three feet or more in length but only about a foot deep. One of the long sides is open completely to the 
elements. When the birds sit on the perch provided near the opening of the long side in these shelter structures they are 
still exposed to conditions such as rain, other precipitation and wind. Exposure to weather conditions such as precipitation 
and cold winds may be detrimental to the health and well-being of the birds. Primary enclosures for birds must be 
constructed and maintained so as to provide shelter and protection for each bird from climatic and environmental 
conditions that may be detrimental. Correct by 11/15/2024. 
3.154  Repeat
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
The facility does not currently have a written plan to address environment enhancement for the bird species maintained. 
The plan must address the social grouping needs, environmental enrichment needs and any special considerations to 
ensure the psychological well-being of the birds. The facility must develop, document, and follow a species-appropriate 
plan for the environment enhancement of birds that is in accordance with currently accepted professional standards and is 
approved by the attending veterinarian. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
